Well the idea has quite a few flaws. For instance: if it is true, then why aren't there as many electrons as positrons? (Taken from Feynman). You could argue that in pair production near a black hole, the positron is absorbed though, leading to the excess electrons.
And there are also problems associated with pair production, which are best described by this comment: https://www.reddit.com/r/AskReddit/comments/5u0kqi/what_mindfucking_paradox_do_you_know/ddsae67/

When an object falls in water, it has to displace a volume of water equal to its own volume for it to have space to fit in the water.
This results in a difference in forces: the downwards and upwards forces that are exerted on the object due to the water should be equal. However, there is a force difference: because the weight of the displaced water is not pushing the object down anymore, the upwards force from the water is larger than that of the downwards force from the water by the weight of the displaced water.
Thus the net force on the object is the weight of the water displaced minus the object's weight. Since the volumes of the displaced water and the object are equal, one can factor the volume out of the force and compare their density. If the water is denser the object rises, and if the object is denser, the object sinks.
You can cheat this rule by increasing the volume of an object without increasing the mass by much. For instance a hollow sphere of iron is larger than a solid cube of iron, even though they have the same mass and thus the same weight. You essentially lower the average density to make the density less than that of water. A car's metal and whatnot is denser than water, but it cheats by having air inside. It's the same principle as a ship: its guts are mostly empty.
I see. Thanks for the advice

WRITING.TITLE: [High School Algebra] Solving the following equation from the birthday problem.
WRITING.TEXT:
Hello.
I've given the birthday problem a try. The problem is stated thus:
What is the minimum number of people necessary such that there is a 50% chance that at least two people share a birthday? Assume that a person is as likely to be born on any day and that a year has 365 days.
I modelled it using a binomial distribution. Consider any day of a year, say for instance February 2nd. The chance that someone is born on this day is 1/365, and no matter the size of the sample, this probability will not change. Therefore the problem can be modelled as a binomial distribution with probability of success 1/365 and with an n number of trials, where n is the number of people.
Now the simplest way to proceed is to calculate the probability that there are no shared birthdays. This can occur only in two ways: either no one has a birthday on that particular day, or only one person has a birthday on that day. The sum of these should be half, because I want the probability of people sharing the same birthday to be half, and thus the probability of nobody having the same birthday should be the same.
The probability that no one has a birthday on that day is (364/365)^n.
The probability that only one person has a birthday on that day is (n/365)*(364/365)^(n - 1).
Now if I add the two, it gives me the probability that no one shares a birthday on only one day. But I want the probability that no one has a birthday for 365 days. Therefore, I want the probability for one day multiplied by itself 365 times, since the probability that no one shares a birthday on a given day is equal regardless of the day. Therefore I raise the sum to the power of 365. The final result is:
`[; \frac 12 = ( \frac {364}{365})^{365n} (1 + \frac {n}{364})^{365} ;]`
I verified that this is the correct solution by plugging in n = 23, and it is. However, I would like to be able to solve the equation, that is manipulate the equation so that I can solve for n, rather than just verifying that it is correct. How can I solve for n from this equation?
Thank you for answering

Partially mathematically and partially physics. Heretic112 explained how the law follows from Noether's theorem. But we also chose our definition of energy such that it was the conserved quantity given by the theorem. For instance kinetic energy used to be mv^2, but 1/2mv^2 is conserved, so that's a better definition for it.
If you are studying calculus as well, I also recommend reading the Feynman Lectures on Physics on the side, especially volume 1. They are available for free online

Consider a ball made of millions of tiny balls and that is stationary. Now suppose that an explosion from inside the balls breaks off one of the tiny balls leaving the others stuck together.
From the centre of mass, the momentum cannot change since no external force was applied on the balls. Therefore, any number of situations that conserve momentum are possible: for instance, the tiny ball could just break off stationary, and the force would be due to a change in mass. However, momentum is not the only conserved quantity: energy must be conserved too. The balls must have released energy to cause the explosion, and this energy must go somewhere. That somewhere is in the kinetic energy of the balls. The only way for both momentum and energy conservation to be satisfied is to have the big ball and the tiny ball move in opposite directions.
Now consider each ball individually. In the explosion, there was a force exerted on the tiny ball, which means that there must be a change in momentum and kinetic energy (by the work-energy theorem). Thus the ball must pick up speed. By Newton's third law, the big ball exerted a force on the small ball and must thus feel a similar force. Using the same momentum and energy arguments, one can show that the big ball must also accelerate, but in the opposite directions. In this case, a force was applied to the large+tiny ball (the original ball) and caused a change in mass, separating it into two. However, this change in mass must also be accompanied by a change in velocity. Thus, while a force can cause a change in mass, it must also cause a change in velocity.
The physical reason for this is that the mass is a scalar property of all objects and it is intrinsic. The mass represents the scalar multiplier in the momentum equation, that is, m is defined as p/v. Mass is, for some reason additive: you can add another object with the same mass as something else and end up with twice the mass (actually the mass is not really additive, but it is a good approximation). Objects are made of elementary particles, such as electrons, which have their own mass. Since mass is additive, the mass of objects is simply the sum of the masses of their elementary particles, and since elementary particles cannot be broken down, the mass of an object is intrinsic. Of course, you can always break the object down and down into smaller pieces, and this would change their mass, but at some point, you won't be able to do that anymore. That means that you can consider objects to be made of tiny little objects; our ball was made of the tiny ball and the large ball, and the mass of these tiny little objects cannot change. That's why the mass of the centre of mass can be constant: the centre of mass is an imaginary point particle so it cannot break any further. A force must therefore cause some acceleration

Ah I think I understood what you meant. In that case, I'll need to show that both expressions are positive before raising them to the fourth power.
The fourth root of 5 must be bigger than one so the left hand side must be positive. Since zero is not a solution to the equation, the right hand side must be positive as well. Therefore, both must be positive. Therefore the solution holds.
I also found a quicker way to solve it: I raise both sides to the 4th power, then I divide the left hand side by the right hand side. If x = 5^0.25, the result is 1.

I'm not sure if it is about understanding something mathematical or whether it is questioning a mathematical concept. Sorry if the thread is in the wrong place.

What I meant by "assume" is that we show it holds for some natural number k. Usually it is 1.
I meant that k and k + 1 don't have fixed values. No matter k is, k + 1 is always different. For instance, I thought that you could suppose k = 2. Then k + 1 = 3. But you could choose k again such that k = 3, thus making the proof invalid. But in changing the value of k, the value of k + 1 also changes, so the proof works.
Dragon Ball Super
But since k is never specified, k could be anything. It holds for one specific value, but that value could be anything. But k + 1 is different from k, so my question is invalid.

We assume that there is some k for which P(k) holds, but k could be any natural number. There is no reason to assume P(2) holds over assuming P(3) holds (of course if you actually show that P(2) holds by plugging 2 in, then P(2) is better than P(3). But you might as well plug in 3 and see if it works). Then you can show that P(k + 1) also holds. What I meant by my question is that since k can be any natural number, it could be k + 1 just be redefining k. But k + 1 is not a value, but an expression, which is itself dependent on k. Thus k and k + 1 are different.

You don't assume anything overall, but the inductive step does require an assumption: that it works for k. Then you can show it works for k + 1. Of course you can define k = 1, then show it holds for one. You don't make any assumptions then.
My question was basically asking whether k and k + 1 are the same thing. They aren't

I like this analogy. You can knock over any domino, and it will knock over the next one, but you definitely knocked over one domino, not the whole series. It illustrates how k can be anything you want it to be, but k + 1 is not the same thing as k.
My confusion came about by thinking of k + 1 as a number rather than an expression. An expression's value is not fixed, so it changes, and thus induction is valid.

The confusion was not in the analysis of the consequences if X was true, but rather in the fact that X is arbitrary, and that X + 1 could easily be taken as a new X. X might be anything, but no matter what X + 1 is distinct from X. This cleared up the confusion.

Hope I'm not butting in. The lower potential is in the direction in which a positive charge would move. In general, this will be closest to the negative charges and furthest from the positive charge: where the electric field is weakest. This means that as you get closer to the negative charges the potential will decrease. It probably is safer to think of the field when looking at how the potential changes: the potential will always decrease in the direction of the electric field, which is the direction in which a positive charge will move. Therefore, the potential is lower the further away you are from a positive charge and the closer you are to a negative charge.

The acceleration cannot be constant if the power is constant. Constant acceleration implies a constant force, and power is defined as work done over time, or Fx/t which can be written as Fv, since v = x/t. (Formally speaking, W = F . dx, so P = F . dx/dt = F . v, which gives a scalar value for the power, and works for non-constant velocity, but the above is good enough).
v is not constant if there is a force being applied, so if Fv is constant, the force and thus the acceleration cannot be constant. In fact, you can show by differentiating the power and then solving the resulting differential equation that the acceleration is exponential, of the form ue^(-t), or -ue^(-t) where u is the initial velocity, t is the time and e is Euler's number. Also, u must not be zero. It is physically impossible to have u = 0 and the power be constant and the object accelerating: if u = 0 then since P = Fv = Fu = 0 in this case, and that the power does not change, the object cannot gain energy to accelerate, if u = 0. However, one can approximate the power as being constant even if u = 0.

WRITING.TITLE: [number theory] Express 1729 as the sum of x^3 + (7 - x)^3.
WRITING.TEXT:
Hello. The title states the question, and there are a few additional details that were given in the question:
1729 = 9^3 + 10^3 = 12^3 + 1^3 = 7(12 + 1)(10+9)
more specifically, they tell me to note that 1729 = 7(12 + 1)(10 + 9), so I guess that's important. I'm supposed to use this, but I'm not sure how. I'm also not allowed to use a calculator.
I expanded x^3 + (7 - x)^3, and obtained a quadratic:
7^3 - (3*49)x + 21x^2 = 7(10 + 9)(12 + 1)
since 7 is common everywhere, I divided to get:
3x^2 - 21x + 49 = (10 + 9)(12 +1) = 120 + 10 + 108 + 9
subtracting 49 on both sides gives:
3x^2 - 21x - 198 = 0 or
x^2 - 7x - 66 = 0
at which point one can apply the quadratic equation to give:
7 313 /////////// 2
Which is pretty much unsolvable without a calculator. And I'm pretty sure my approach is wrong, because I did not use what was given in the question.
I noticed that 7(12 + 1)(9 + 10) has 12 + 1 and 9 + 10, which are similar to 12^3 + 1^3 and 9^3 + 10^3, and I have a feeling that this is important, but I don't know how it is important.
Thanks for any answers

WRITING.TEXT:

`[; \frac {x + 1}{x - 1} = ( \frac {3 + 2x}{3 - 2x})^{0.25} ;] `
I rewrote the denominator on the left hand side as x^4 - 1, by multiplying it by the respective conjugates, and multiplied the numerator as well. Probably the biggest in the series: He tried to blow up Namek, begged for forgiveness, killed an entire race out of fear, tried to kill the person who spared him using his own energy from behind no less, tried to blow up Earth when he was losing against Trunks, tried to attack those on the sidelines vs Goku post-revival, got a soldier to strike him from the back again, and blew up the Earth when he saw he was losing.
Cell wasn't really that much of a pussy. He did run away from Piccolo and the others, but only so that he could become more powerful. Can't really accuse him too much of that, otherwise the whole cast of Z-fighters would be cowards during the Cell and Buu arc. More of a tactical retreat, against Piccolo and Vegeta. He chickened out against the Final Flash, and attempted to destroy the Earth in order to hit Goku, and tried to blow himself up against Gohan, but that's about it.
Buu's absorption doesn't really count as cowardice in my opinion. It was his ability, which he used in a fight, and it is no different than say, instant transmission or the fusion technique. If anything, his insanity and cunning make him the bravest of all foes.
Zamasu was not really a coward either. He did act like a coward at times, but it was more cunning and tactical action rather than just cowardice. Of course, he was immortal, so that gives him a lot more leeway, but still, he did that not to escape his opponents, but because he had a plan. Trunks was a much bigger coward in the arc.

WRITING.TITLE: Is induction a valid proof?
WRITING.TEXT:
Hello. I have trouble seeing how induction, strong or weak can act as a proof.
The principle of weak induction states that If some property P(k) were to hold for k, where P(k) is some property, and k is a natural number, and P(1) also holds, then P(k + 1) is also true.
In assuming that P(k) holds, don't we already assume that P holds for any natural number? Since k is any natural number you could choose any k, and assume that P(k) holds for it. If k is a natural number, then so is k + 1, but since k can be anything you choose it to be, you could just pick another number, lets say C, and then say C is k + 1. Then you would have P(C), where C is any natural number, but by assumption this already holds.
Strong induction seems even more guilty of this: if it holds for 1...k, then it holds for k + 1. If I choose some other number C such that C = k + 1, then by assumption the property holds for 1...C, so not only does this suggest it holds for C, it also holds for k.
What did I miss?
Thank you for answering

WRITING.TITLE: Lamy Al-Star Medium nib a bit scratchy
WRITING.TEXT:
Hello. So I got a Lamy Al-Star (graphite coloured one) recently. Normally the pen has a medium nib upon sale, but I asked for a fine one (I've always been a sucker for thin lines) , and the nice shopkeeper gave me the medium one for free as a bonus. The fine nib was sold separate from the pen so it was fresh, while the medium nib was on the pen already. I doubt it was tested often, because the pen was locked away and you had to go through a long process just to test the pen.
So I tried the fine nib first, and it felt like I had killed an angel and was eating its succulent meat. I wrote so much, I had to change the cartridge, which was a free Lamy blue one offered with the pen. I used Lamy black. I also swapped the nib for the medium one.
And the medium one seems to have a very small sweet spot. It seems that I need to hold it just right, or else the line is just a scratchier fine. At a certain, restrictive angle it writes very well, with lines the size of a medium, but the moment I deviate just a little bit from that, it becomes a bit scratchier, and the lines become thinner. Not so scratchy that it can't write, but it does feel unpleasant.
And when I write quickly, it skips a little or the line thins significantly, especially when curling the gs's and the ys's tails. And while the fine nib could write with the back of nib rather smoothly, the medium nib cannot even do so, unless it is at a very awkward angle, where the pen is completely upright and writes from the tip of the nib rather than the back. And even then, it skips a lot.
It cannot be the ink, because I switched the nibs to try, and the fine writes just as well. It also writes just as smoothly at angles at which the medium scratches.
Anybody tried both nibs and experienced the same thing? And anyone has some advice on what to do about the nib?
Thanks for the replies
